description.summary: a protocol for low overhead screen content capturing

protocol.description:
An interface to capture surfaces in an efficient way. Overall usage:
1.) client registers with zwlr_screencontent_manager_v1 2.) server sends client info about surfaces via "receive_surface_info" 3.) client subscribes to capture a surface via the "capture" requests 4.) server sends client events via the "zwlr_screencontent_frame" interface 5.) client finishes and informs server via the "frame_destroy" event 6.) client optionally resubscribes via repeating steps 3.) through 5.)

interface.name: zwlr_export_dmabuf_frame_v1
interface.description:
This object represents a frame which is ready to have its resources fetched and used.
The receive callback shall be called first, followed by the "object" callback once per dmabuf object or the "layer" callback, once per dmabuf layer. The "plane" callback shall only be called after the "layer" callback corresponding to the layer the plane belongs to has been called Finally, the "ready" event is called to indicate that all the data has been made available for readout, as well as the time at which presentation happened at. The ownership of the frame is passed to the client, who's responsible for destroying it via the "destroy" event once finished. The data the API describes has been based off of what VASurfaceAttribExternalBuffers contains. All frames are read-only and may not be written into or altered.

enum.name: flags
enum.description: Special flags that must be respected by the client. Transient frames indicate short lifetime frames (such as swapchain images from external clients). Clients are advised to copy them and do all processing outside of the "ready" event.

event.name: frame
event.description:
Main callback supplying the client with information about the frame, as well as an object to serve as context for destruction. Always called first before any other events.
The "transform" argument describes the orientation needed to be applied to correctly orient the buffer. For example, a buffer rotated by 90 degrees will have a value of "3" here, corresponding to the need to apply a 270 degree transpose to correctly present the buffer.

arg.name: width
arg.summary: frame width, scaling factor included

arg.name: height
arg.summary: frame height, scaling factor included

arg.name: scale
arg.summary: current scaling factor of the client

arg.name: transform
arg.summary: transform needed to correct the orientation, has the same values as wl_output::transform

arg.name: buffer_flags
arg.summary: flags which indicate properties (invert, interlacing), has the same values as zwp_linux_buffer_params_v1:flags

arg.name: flags
arg.summary: indicates special frame features

arg.name: mod_high
arg.summary: drm format modifier, high

arg.name: mod_low
arg.summary: drm format modifier, low

arg.name: num_objects
arg.summary: indicates how many objects (FDs) the frame has (max 4)

arg.name: num_layers
arg.summary: indicates how many layers the frame has (max 4)

event.name: object
event.description: Callback which serves to supply the client with the file descriptors containing the data for each object.

arg.name: index
arg.summary: index of the current object

arg.name: fd
arg.summary: fd of the current object

arg.name: size
arg.summary: size in bytes for the current object

event.name: layer
event.description: Callback which serves to supply the client with information on what's contained in each file descriptor and how its laid out. Will be called after the main receive event, once per layer.

arg.name: index
arg.summary: index of the current plane

arg.name: format
arg.summary: format of the layer (DRM_FORMAT_*)

arg.name: num_planes
arg.summary: number of planes in the current layer (max 4)

event.name: plane
event.description: Callback which supplies the client with plane information for each layer.

arg.name: index
arg.summary: index of the current plane

arg.name: layer_index
arg.summary: index of the current layer

arg.name: object_index
arg.summary: index of the object the plane applies to

arg.name: offset
arg.summary: starting point for the data in the object's fd

arg.name: stride
arg.summary: line size in bytes

event.name: ready

description.summary: indicates frame is available for reading

event.description: Called as soon as the frame is presented, indicating it is available for reading. The timestamp is expressed as tv_sec_hi, tv_sec_lo, tv_nsec triples, each component being an unsigned 32-bit value. Whole seconds are in tv_sec which is a 64-bit value combined from tv_sec_hi and tv_sec_lo, and the additional fractional part in tv_nsec as nanoseconds. Hence, for valid timestamps tv_nsec must be in [0, 999999999]. The seconds part may have an arbitrary offset at start.

arg.name: tv_sec_hi
arg.summary: high 32 bits of the seconds part of the timestamp

arg.name: tv_sec_lo
arg.summary: low 32 bits of the seconds part of the timestamp

arg.name: tv_nsec
arg.summary: nanoseconds part of the timestamp

enum.name: abort_reason
enum.description: Indicates reason for aborting the frame.

entry.name: invalid_source
entry.summary: invalid source, will not produce any (more) frames

entry.name: resizing
entry.summary: source started being resized, this frame must be dropped, but source is still able to be captured

entry.name: security
entry.summary: this frame must be dropped as sensitive data was present, however future capture may still succeed

event.name: abort

description.summary: indicates the frame is no longer valid

event.description: If the frame is no longer valid after the "frame" event has been called, this callback will be used to inform the client to scrap the frame. Source is still valid for as long as the subscription function does not return NULL. This may get called if for instance the surface is in the process of resizing.

arg.name: reason
arg.summary: indicates a reason for aborting this frame capture

request.name: destroy

description.summary: delete this object, used or not

request.description: Unreferences the frame, allowing it to be reused. Must be called as soon as its no longer used.

interface.name: zwlr_export_dmabuf_manager_v1

description.summary: manager to inform clients and begin capturing

interface.description: This object is a manager which informs clients about capturable windows and is able to create callbacks from which to begin to receive content from. The "title" argument in the "surface_info" event shall be used to provide a user-readable identifier such as a window title or program name.

event.name: surface_info
event.description: This will be called whenever a surface that's able to be captured appears.

arg.name: title
arg.summary: window title or an identifier

arg.name: id
arg.summary: an identifier to create a context with

event.name: surface_unavailable

description.summary: notifies of a surface being unavailable to capture

event.description: Called if a surface becomes unavailable to capture, for example if has been closed.

arg.name: id
arg.summary: an identifier of the surface

request.name: capture_client
request.description: Request to start capturing from a surface with a given id.

arg.name: overlay_cursor
arg.summary: include custom client hardware cursor on top of the frame

arg.name: id
arg.summary: an identifier to start capturing from

request.name: capture_output
request.description: Request to start capturing from an entire wl_output.

arg.name: overlay_cursor
arg.summary: include custom client hardware cursor on top of the frame

request.name: destroy
request.description: All objects created by the manager will still remain valid, until their appropriate destroy request has been called.
